study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between PDE1 and asthma, and whether Vinpocetine, as a PDE1 inhibitor, could mitigate allergic lung inflammation induced by ovalbumin (OVA).
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly reduced airway hyper-responsiveness, inflammatory cell counts (especially eosinophils), and OVA-specific IgE levels. It also decreased interleukin-13 and regulated MIP-1β release and mRNA expression, suggesting PDE1 inhibitors like Vinpocetine may be a promising asthma treatment.
population_specificity: Balb/c mice sensitized and challenged with OVA.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intraperitoneal administration 1 hour before challenge).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effect of vinpocetine in treating acute pancreatitis by examining its anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and antiapoptotic properties.
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly ameliorated oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis in acute pancreatitis, improving serum enzyme levels, antioxidant capacity, and histological markers while reducing inflammatory cytokines and caspase-3 activity.
population_specificity: Adult male albino Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate the effectiveness of Vinpocetine as a treatment for acquired sensorineural hearing loss by modulating voltage-sensitive sodium channels.
results_summary: The study found that Vinpocetine initially did not prevent hearing impairment in the first 6 months, but from 6 to 12 months, it significantly improved hearing capacity and halted further deterioration.
population_specificity: Patients older than 18 years with acquired sensorineural hearing loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Vinpocetine affects microglial PDE1-B expression, autophagic flux, exosome biogenesis, and neuronal survival under ischemic conditions.
results_summary: Vinpocetine inhibited PDE1-B in microglial cells, promoting M2 phenotype and suppressing M1 phenotype via enhanced autophagy, which alleviated neuronal damage in ischemic conditions. Exosomes from Vinpocetine-treated microglia regulated neuronal survival both in vitro and in vivo.
population_specificity: BV2 microglial cells and neurons in an oxygen-glucose-deprivation (OGD) ischemic model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinpocetine could prevent the formation and progression of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in mice and explore its potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Vinpocetine pre-treatment significantly reduced aneurysmal dilation and suppressed the progression of pre-existing moderate AAA. It improved cellular and molecular changes associated with AAA, such as elastin degradation and inflammation, by inhibiting NF-κB activation and proinflammatory mediator expression.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice with induced AAA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of vinpocetine, alone and in combination with sorafenib, to treat hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) by examining its antiproliferative effects and autophagy modulation.
results_summary: Vinpocetine showed antiproliferative activity in HCC cells but induced cytoprotective autophagy, limiting its antitumor effects. Combining vinpocetine with sorafenib suppressed autophagy, enhanced apoptosis, and inhibited cell proliferation more effectively than either drug alone, suggesting a synergistic anti-HCC effect via GSK-3β activation.
population_specificity: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-neuroinflammatory effects of vinpocetine on LPS-stimulated BV2 microglia and its potential mechanism involving AMPK phosphorylation.
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly reduced nitric oxide production, pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β), and inflammatory mediators (iNOS, COX-2) in a dose-dependent manner. It also increased AMPK phosphorylation, and AMPK inhibition blocked its anti-inflammatory effects, suggesting AMPK activation as a key mechanism.
population_specificity: BV2 microglia (a murine microglial cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Vinpocetine's potential to attenuate liver fibrosis induced by thioacetamide (TAA) in rats, focusing on oxidative stress, inflammation, angiogenesis, and proliferation.
results_summary: Vinpocetine reduced liver injury markers, oxidative stress, and fibrosis indicators (hydroxyproline, α-SMA), while also lowering inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, TNF-α) and inhibiting angiogenesis/proliferation (VEGF/Ki-67). The study demonstrated Vinpocetine's anti-fibrotic effects in TAA-induced liver fibrosis.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley rats with TAA-induced liver fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a transdermal fast-dissolving microneedle patch of Vinpocetine to improve bioavailability, prolong half-life, and reduce dosing frequency compared to oral tablets.
results_summary: The optimized microneedle patch showed enhanced skin penetrability, a 9-fold increase in ex vivo permeation, a 3-fold rise in relative bioavailability, and prolonged release (half-life of 14 h) in rats, with high cell viability (94.27%) indicating safety.
population_specificity: Sprague Dawley rats (in vivo), HaCaT cells (in vitro), and pig ear skin (ex vivo).
effective_dosage: Optimized formulation contained Vinpocetine at 5 mol% in ultradeformable liposomes.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effect of vinpocetine, alone or combined with PPT, against ovariectomy-induced dementia in rodents.
results_summary: Vinpocetine improved cognitive deficits, cholinergic function, and cGMP/cAMP ratio in brain regions of ovariectomized rodents. It also attenuated PPT-induced side effects, suggesting a safer combination therapy.
population_specificity: Female ovariectomized rodents (rats).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop biodegradable Vinpocetine nanoparticles to improve its oral bioavailability, prolong its elimination half-life, and enhance brain delivery.
results_summary: The optimized nanoparticle formulation achieved a particle size of 43 nm and 82% drug entrapment, significantly enhancing bioavailability, prolonging systemic exposure, and increasing brain levels in Wistar rats.
population_specificity: Wistar rats
effective_dosage: 200 mg of PEG-PLGA polymer (PEG: PLGA 2000: 4,500), 0.5% polyvinyl alcohol, sonication time of 60 s

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding vinpocetine to dexamethasone could enhance anti-inflammatory and anti-oxidative effects in NPC patients with radiation-induced brain injury.
results_summary: Combined vinpocetine and dexamethasone therapy reduced inflammatory cytokines, increased antioxidants, decreased oxidants, and improved cognitive function compared to dexamethasone alone.
population_specificity: 60 NPC patients with radiation-related brain injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and mechanisms of vinpocetine in protecting against cisplatin-induced acute kidney injury in an animal model.
results_summary: Vinpocetine reduced cisplatin-induced renal function damage and tubular injury by inhibiting the NF-κB signaling pathway and activating the Nrf2/ARE signaling pathway, demonstrating protective effects in both in vivo and in vitro experiments.
population_specificity: Rats (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Vinpocetine's neurological effects, including its potential in managing ischemic stroke, epilepsy, depression, and cognitive deficits.
results_summary: Vinpocetine demonstrated antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anti-apoptotic effects, reduced seizure frequency by 50% at 2 mg/kg/day, improved psychomotor performance, and enhanced cognitive functions through modulation of brain pathways.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or in vitro models based on mechanisms described).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic and preserving effects of vinpocetine on amyloid beta-induced cognitive and memory impairment in a rat model of Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: Vinpocetine ameliorated memory deficits in Aβ-induced rats, improving performance in learning and memory tests (MWM, PAL, NOR) and reducing oxidative stress markers (nitric oxide, malondialdehyde) while restoring glutathione levels.
population_specificity: Male adult Wistar rats (n=60) divided into 6 groups.
study_duration: 30 days (pre-treatment or treatment) or 60 days (pre-treatment + treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Vinpocetine could inhibit osteoclast activity and differentiation, potentially serving as a treatment for osteoporosis.
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly inhibited osteoclast formation and bone resorption in vitro, suppressed osteoclast-specific gene expression, and reduced signaling pathways involved in osteoclastogenesis. Animal studies showed Vinpocetine attenuated bone loss and improved serum markers related to bone health.
population_specificity: In vitro osteoclasts and ovariectomized animals (modeling postmenopausal osteoporosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Vinpocetine's potential as a therapeutic compound for a woman with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome due to a Y302C GABRB3 mutation.
results_summary: Vinpocetine enhanced GABRB3 channel conductance, reduced spike-wave discharge frequency, and improved language, behavior, and global impression of change. The effects were dose-dependent and sustained over 6 months.
population_specificity: A woman with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome caused by a Y302C GABRB3 mutation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of vinpocetine as an adjuvant treatment for focal epilepsy in patients already on antiepileptic drugs.
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly reduced seizure frequency compared to placebo (69% vs. 13% achieving ≥50% reduction) with no significant differences in adverse effects, demonstrating good tolerability.
population_specificity: 87 patients with focal epilepsy on 1-3 antiepileptic drugs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of vinpocetine in an aluminum-induced Alzheimer's disease model under social isolation conditions.
results_summary: Vinpocetine improved cognitive performance in the Morris water maze test, exhibited anti-depressive effects in the forced swimming test, and reversed pathological and biochemical markers of Alzheimer's disease, including amyloid-β, phosphorylated-tau, oxidative stress, and inflammation.
population_specificity: Aluminum-treated rats subjected to social isolation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinpocetine could alleviate schizophrenia-like deficits induced by ketamine in rats by regulating BDNF-related PSD-95 and reversing synaptic ultrastructure changes.
results_summary: Vinpocetine improved schizophrenia-like behaviors, increased PSD-95 protein levels by upregulating BDNF expression, and reversed synaptic ultrastructure changes in the posterior cingulate cortex.
population_specificity: Rats with ketamine-induced schizophrenia-like deficits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of vinpocetine on mitochondrial bioenergetics, focusing on calcium uptake, respiration, and reactive oxygen species production in brain cells.
results_summary: Vinpocetine partially inhibited mitochondrial calcium efflux, reduced H2O2 release, stimulated leak respiration but inhibited ADP-induced respiration, and mitigated Ca2+-induced mitochondrial swelling. It also lowered ATP synthesis while increasing ATPase activity.
population_specificity: Primary brain capillary endothelial cells, rodent brain synaptosomes, and isolated rat brain mitochondria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of vinpocetine in a model of superoxide anion-induced pain and inflammation to assess its potential as an anti-inflammatory and analgesic drug.
results_summary: Vinpocetine dose-dependently reduced pain-like behaviors, inflammation, and oxidative stress markers while restoring antioxidant capacity and inhibiting pro-inflammatory cytokine production in a mouse model.
population_specificity: Mice (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinpocetine's anti-inflammatory properties could provide a protective effect in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: Vinpocetine reduced pro-inflammatory markers (TLR2/4, MyD88, NF-κB, TNF-α, MCP-1) and increased anti-inflammatory markers (TLR3, TRIF-β, IRF-3, IL-10, IL-8), while also improving cognitive function compared to traditional therapy.
population_specificity: 89 Parkinson's disease patients and 42 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardioprotective effects of vinpocetine, both alone and in combination with nimodipine, in a rat model of myocardial infarction induced by isoproterenol.
results_summary: Vinpocetine (10 mg/kg) alone and in combination with nimodipine significantly restored antioxidant status, hemodynamic parameters, cellular architecture, and ultrastructural changes in the heart, demonstrating cardioprotective effects. The combination therapy showed better restoration of oxidative stress, cardiac membrane damage, and histopathological changes compared to monotherapy.
population_specificity: Rats with isoproterenol-induced myocardial infarction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and analgesic effects of vinpocetine in a mouse model of acetic acid-induced colitis.
results_summary: Vinpocetine reduced edema, MPO activity, microscopic and macroscopic damage, and visceral mechanical hyperalgesia. It also prevented reductions in GSH levels, improved ABTS radical scavenging, normalized IL-10 levels, and reduced NF-κB activation and pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, TNF-α, IL-33).
population_specificity: Mice with acetic acid-induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of vinpocetine against ketamine-induced schizophrenia-like deficits in rats and elucidate its potential mechanisms of neuroprotection.
results_summary: Vinpocetine pre-treatment significantly improved hyperlocomotion, anxiety, and short-term memory deficits induced by ketamine, attenuated oxidative stress and inflammation, elevated BDNF expression, and prevented ketamine-induced stimulation of the GSK-3β/β-catenin pathway.
population_specificity: Rats with ketamine-induced schizophrenia-like deficits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinpocetine exerts neuroprotective effects by inhibiting TLR4-mediated inflammatory responses in cerebral ischemia/reperfusion injury.
results_summary: Vinpocetine reduced cerebral infarct volumes, improved neurological scores, decreased cell death markers, and increased neuron viability in both mouse and cell models by inhibiting TLR4/MyD88/NF-κB signaling.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO) and cultured cortical neurons exposed to oxygen-glucose deprivation (OGD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the novel therapeutic effects and mechanisms of Vinpocetine, including its potential for treating cerebrovascular disorders, cognitive enhancement, and other newly identified functions like anti-inflammation and vascular protection.
results_summary: The study found that Vinpocetine has been safely used for over 30 years in treating cerebrovascular disorders and exhibits novel functions such as anti-inflammation, vascular remodeling antagonism, and attenuation of pathological cardiac remodeling, suggesting potential for broader therapeutic applications.
population_specificity: Humans with cerebrovascular disorders, cognitive impairment, or conditions involving inflammation and vascular pathology.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-fibrotic and therapeutic efficacy of vinpocetine in mice infected with Schistosoma mansoni, comparing its effects to isosorbide-5-mononitrate and praziquantel.
results_summary: Vinpocetine monotherapy significantly decreased hepatic nuclear factor-kappaB but was less effective than isosorbide-5-mononitrate in reducing liver fibrosis markers like hydroxyproline and collagen. The study suggests vinpocetine has potential anti-fibrotic effects but is inferior to isosorbide-5-mononitrate as an adjuvant to praziquantel.
population_specificity: Swiss albino female mice experimentally infected with an Egyptian strain of Schistosoma mansoni.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether vinpocetine could mitigate diabetes-associated renal damage in rats.
results_summary: Vinpocetine treatment reduced blood glucose, renal damage markers, and oxidative stress while improving kidney structure and function. It also modulated cytokine production and restored nephrin and podocin expression.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with streptozotocin-induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of vinpocetine for treating poststroke cognitive dysfunction (PSCD) through a systematic review of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that vinpocetine's efficacy for PSCD is still inconclusive, and the study plans to evaluate existing RCTs to provide clearer evidence. No specific results are mentioned, as this is a protocol for a systematic review.
population_specificity: Patients with poststroke cognitive dysfunction (PSCD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinpocetine, as an inflammation modulator, could improve clinical outcomes in patients with acute ischemic stroke.
results_summary: Vinpocetine inhibited nuclear factor kappa-light-chain-enhancer of activated B cell activation, reduced secondary lesion enlargement, attenuated inflammation, and led to better neurological recovery and improved clinical outcomes compared to controls.
population_specificity: 60 patients with anterior cerebral circulation occlusion and stroke onset between 4.5 and 48 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective and nootropic effects of vinpocetine in treating cerebral vascular disorders and ischemic brain damage.
results_summary: Vinpocetine demonstrated an increase in cerebral blood flow and neuroprotective effects, with mechanisms differing from other antioxidants like 2-ethyl-6-methyl-3-hydroxypyridine-succinate. Clinical and biological model studies supported its efficacy in improving cerebral metabolism.
population_specificity: Patients with cerebral vascular disorders and ischemic brain damage (specific details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect and mechanisms of vinpocetine in a model of diclofenac-induced acute kidney injury (AKI).
results_summary: Vinpocetine reduced diclofenac-induced increases in blood urea, creatinine, oxidative stress, apoptosis, proinflammatory cytokines, and NF-κB activation in renal tissue, demonstrating protective effects against diclofenac-induced AKI.
population_specificity: Preclinical model (animal study, specific species not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a mixed micelle system combined with borneol could improve the brain-targeting efficiency and bioavailability of orally delivered vinpocetine.
results_summary: The study found that the mixed micelle system enhanced drug-loading, stability, in vitro release, bioavailability, and brain-targeting effects of vinpocetine, with the targeting efficiency being dependent on the dose of borneol.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and/or animal model implied, but not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinpocetine pre-treatment could protect retinal neurons against future ischemic damage in an ex vivo model.
results_summary: Vinpocetine pre-treatment reduced cation channel permeability, decreased apoptotic marker immunoreactivity, increased parvalbumin immunoreactivity in inner retinal neurons, and reduced Müller cell reactivity following ischemic insults, though many effects were transient.
population_specificity: Ex vivo retinal tissue subjected to ischemia.
study_duration: Up to 120 minutes of ischemic insult.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of vinpocetine on the phenotype and function of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) and explore its potential mechanism as an immunomodulatory agent.
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly downregulated pro-inflammatory markers (CD40, CD80, CD86) on pDCs, increased expression of its receptor TSPO, inhibited Toll-like receptor 9 signaling, reduced cytokine secretion, and promoted pDC viability. These findings suggest vinpocetine may modulate pDC function for autoimmune disease treatment.
population_specificity: pDCs isolated from C57BL/6 mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a novel ionic cocrystal of vinpocetine to improve its solubility and pharmacokinetic properties, including bioavailability.
results_summary: The study found that the new ionic cocrystal of vinpocetine with boric acid significantly improved solubilization kinetics and key pharmacokinetic parameters (Cmax, tmax, AUC), suggesting enhanced bioavailability compared to existing formulations.
population_specificity: Human pilot study (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the potential protective effects of vinpocetine and VIP against manganese (Mn)-induced toxicity in NE-4C neural stem cells.
results_summary: Vinpocetine at 2 μM significantly reduced Mn-induced LDH leakage, ROS production, membrane degradation, and apoptosis, while also attenuating mitochondrial membrane potential decrease. The study suggests vinpocetine exerts protective effects by modulating oxidative stress and apoptosis in Mn-induced neurodegeneration.
population_specificity: NE-4C neural stem cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinpocetine could reverse neural plasticity-related protein changes induced by early ethanol exposure in rats.
results_summary: Vinpocetine did not alter behavioral outcomes but induced changes in neural plasticity-related proteins, such as increasing mitogen-activated protein kinase phosphatase in the prefrontal cortex and phosphorylated-glycogen synthase kinase β in the dorsal hippocampus.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats exposed to ethanol during early development (P4-P9) and treated with vinpocetine from P25-P31.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinpocetine could inhibit the osteoblastic differentiation of vascular smooth muscle cells, a key process in vascular calcification.
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly reduced osteoblast-like phenotypes in vascular smooth muscle cells, including ALP activity, osteocalcin, collagen type I, Runx2, and BMP-2 expression, as well as mineralized nodule formation. It achieved this by binding to translocation protein, inducing phosphorylation of ERK and Akt, and inhibiting NF-kappa B nuclear translocation.
population_specificity: Beta-glycerophosphate-induced vascular smooth muscle cell model (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinpocetine could reverse scopolamine-induced cognitive deficits in animals, particularly focusing on memory dysfunction.
results_summary: Vinpocetine (4 mg/kg) administered for 28 days significantly improved scopolamine-induced memory dysfunction in behavioral tests (open field, Y-maze). Lower doses (2 mg/kg) showed some beneficial effects on emotional memory in fear conditioning tests.
population_specificity: Memory-deficient mice (scopolamine-induced cognitive impairment model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether vinpocetine, a selective PDE1 inhibitor, could mitigate cognitive deficits, cholinergic dysfunction, oxidative stress, and tissue damage in mice with chronic cerebral hypoperfusion-induced vascular dementia.
results_summary: Vinpocetine treatment reduced learning and memory deficits, limited cholinergic dysfunction, decreased oxidative stress, and reduced brain infarct size in mice with chronic cerebral hypoperfusion.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to bilateral common carotid arteries ligation (2VO) to induce chronic cerebral hypoperfusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential for pharmacokinetic drug interactions involving vinpocetine by assessing its effects on CYPs, P-gp, and PXR.
results_summary: Vinpocetine strongly inhibited P-gp and moderately inhibited CYP3A4 and CYP2D6, but had no effect on other CYP enzymes. PXR activation was observed only at the highest tested concentration (30 µM).
population_specificity: In vitro studies using recombinant enzymes, transfected and wild-type MDCKII cells, and HepG2 cells.
effective_dosage: Concentrations up to 30 µM were tested.
interactions: Potential interactions with P-gp substrates and weak interactions with CYP3A4 and CYP2D6 substrates.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the analgesic effect of vinpocetine and its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant mechanisms in murine inflammatory pain models.
results_summary: Vinpocetine inhibited pain-like behavior induced by acetic acid, PBQ, and formalin, as well as carrageenan-induced hyperalgesia and neutrophil recruitment. It also reduced oxidative stress, cytokine production, and NF-κB activation in both peripheral tissues and the spinal cord.
population_specificity: Murine (mice) models of inflammatory pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of vinpocetine pre-treatment on hyperalgesia, leukocyte recruitment, oxidative stress, and pro-inflammatory cytokine production in response to LPS-induced inflammation in mice and RAW 264.7 macrophages.
results_summary: Vinpocetine (30mg/kg) significantly reduced hyperalgesia, leukocyte recruitment, oxidative stress, and pro-inflammatory cytokine production (TNF-α, IL-1β, and IL-33) in mice, and inhibited NF-κB activation and cytokine production in LPS-stimulated macrophages.
population_specificity: Mice (in vivo) and RAW 264.7 macrophages (in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize Vinpocetine's effects on metabolism, particularly in the context of ischemia, using the ischemic retina as a model.
results_summary: Vinpocetine reduced metabolic demand in the retina following hypoxia and ischemia, normalized lactate dehydrogenase activity, improved glucose availability, and enhanced glutamate homeostasis in Müller cells. It also reduced cell death and improved retinal function, suggesting metabolic and non-metabolic protective effects.
population_specificity: Ischemic retina (ex vivo and in vivo models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Vinpocetine (Cognitol™) in improving memory and concentration in cognitively impaired patients.
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly improved memory and concentration in cognitively impaired patients, though efficacy was minimal in demented patients. Patients showed significant cognitive improvements at 6 and 12 weeks compared to baseline.
population_specificity: 56 cognitively impaired patients (with epilepsy and dementia) compared to 56 age, sex, and education-matched controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined vinpocetine and ozagrel administration improves behavioral recovery in rats after global brain ischemia.
results_summary: The study found that combined vinpocetine and ozagrel treatment led to significantly better behavioral recovery compared to single-drug administration, particularly in cognition and motor behavior. The results suggest potential benefits for brain ischemia patients.
population_specificity: Rats with global brain ischemia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of vinpocetine, a PDE1 inhibitor, on motor deficits and oxidative-nitrosative stress in an MPTP-induced Parkinson's disease rat model.
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly and dose-dependently improved movement disabilities, reduced oxidative-nitrosative stress, and restored cyclic nucleotide and dopamine levels in MPTP-treated rats.
population_specificity: Rats with MPTP-induced Parkinson's disease-like symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of vinpocetine on hyperglycemia-facilitated neointimal hyperplasia and explore its possible mechanism in diabetic and nondiabetic rats.
results_summary: Vinpocetine prevented intimal hyperplasia in carotid arteries in both normal and diabetic animals, inhibited VSMC proliferation, chemokinesis, ROS generation, and apoptotic resistance induced by high glucose, and affected key signaling pathways (MAPK, PI3K/Akt, NF-κB).
population_specificity: Nondiabetic and diabetic rats subjected to carotid artery balloon injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether phosphodiesterase inhibitors, including vinpocetine, could influence myelin repair in oligodendroglial precursor cells.
results_summary: Vinpocetine had a strong negative effect on myelin expression and decreased morphological complexities, suggesting impaired oligodendroglial cell maturation. This effect was mediated via inhibition of IĸB kinase, not phosphodiesterase-1.
population_specificity: Primary oligodendroglial precursor cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore Vinpocetine's role in inhibiting microglial inflammation and its potential neuroprotective effects in vitro and in hypoxic mice.
results_summary: Vinpocetine inhibited inflammatory factors (IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α) and NF-κB/AP-1 expression in microglia, demonstrating anti-inflammatory effects. It also protected primary neurons and reduced inflammation in hypoxic mice.
population_specificity: BV-2 microglia (in vitro) and hypoxic mice (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the vasodilating effect of vinpocetine in patients with cerebral small vessel disease (SVD) by measuring cerebral vasomotor reactivity (VMR).
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant increase in breath holding index (BHI) on the right MCA and improvements in MMSE and mRS scores after three months of vinpocetine treatment, suggesting potential benefits for cerebral VMR and cognitive/functional status. However, the left MCA BHI increase did not reach statistical significance.
population_specificity: 30 patients with cerebral small vessel disease (SVD), average age 61.4 years (60% female, 40% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review studies investigating the role of vinpocetine in cerebrovascular diseases, focusing on its neuroprotective and cerebral blood-flow enhancing effects.
results_summary: Vinpocetine demonstrated cerebral blood-flow enhancing and neuroprotective effects, with no significant side effects reported, making it safe for long-term use. It is marketed for vasodilation and memory improvement.
population_specificity: Not specified (general cerebrovascular disease context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of vinpocetine on human breast cancer cells, including its impact on proliferation, apoptosis, migration, and tumor growth in a xenograft model.
results_summary: Vinpocetine inhibited proliferation of multiple breast cancer cell types by arresting the cell cycle at G(0)/G(1) phase, induced apoptosis via mitochondria-dependent pathways, and impaired migration of metastatic cells. In a xenograft model, vinpocetine significantly suppressed tumor growth without observed toxicity.
population_specificity: Human breast cancer cells (in vitro) and nude mice with xenografted human breast cancer (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of just-in-time programming of visual scene displays in AAC intervention for adults with severe intellectual and developmental disabilities who are beginning communicators.
results_summary: All participants showed increased intentional and conventional communication turns during social interaction with the intervention, without discontinuing other communication modes. The approach shows promise for adults with severe disabilities at a beginning communicator level.
population_specificity: Adults (ages 29-48) with severe intellectual and developmental disabilities who are beginning communicators.
study_duration: Minimum of five baseline and five intervention sessions (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of video visual scene displays (video VSDs) on communication during social interactions between adolescents with ASD and peer partners.
results_summary: All four adolescents with ASD showed increased communicative turns and modes of communication after using video VSDs, with three participants also demonstrating increased speech use. Both participants and peer partners expressed interest in continued use of the app.
population_specificity: Adolescents with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and complex communication needs in a high school setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of the Transition to Literacy (T2L) feature within video visual scene displays (VSDs) on single-word reading of academic vocabulary in a pre-literate adolescent with cerebral palsy and minimal speech.
results_summary: The adolescent successfully acquired all 12 target words with minimal exposure to written words through the app and demonstrated generalization to novel tasks. The study reported very large effects across all word sets using Tau-U analysis.
population_specificity: Pre-literate adolescent with cerebral palsy and minimal speech.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of video visual scene displays (video VSDs) as an intervention to enhance independent participation in volunteer activities for individuals with severe disabilities and complex communication needs.
results_summary: The study found that all four participants mastered the volunteer activity and communication exchanges using video VSDs, suggesting the intervention may effectively support skill acquisition and social interaction in this population.
population_specificity: Four adolescents with autism spectrum disorder or Down syndrome, all with complex communication needs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of intravenous vinpocetine as part of a comprehensive treatment for acute cerebral infarction in a Chinese population.
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly improved cognitive skills, neurological function, and quality of life compared to the control group, with increased cerebral blood flow and no significant safety differences. These benefits were maintained over time.
population_specificity: 610 acute cerebral infarction patients in a Chinese population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of tablet-based augmentative and alternative communication technology with video visual scene displays (video VSDs) and instruction on communication between a child with ASD and a typically developing peer during pretend play.
results_summary: The intervention led to an increase in symbolic communicative turns by the child with ASD across all three play activities, with a large overall effect size. The results suggest preliminary support for video VSDs in enhancing communication for children with ASD during peer play.
population_specificity: One dyad consisting of a child with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and limited speech and a peer with typical development.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-tech visual scene displays (VSDs) and low-tech isolated picture symbols on engagement in beginning communicators with multiple disabilities.
results_summary: All three participants showed greater engagement with high-tech VSDs than low-tech isolated picture symbols, as measured by gaze duration. However, no clear difference was observed in engagement toward the communication partner or AAC use between the two conditions.
population_specificity: Elementary-age beginning communicators with multiple disabilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an intervention using aided AAC technologies with visual scene displays (VSDs) and "just-in-time" (JIT) programming could increase symbolic communication turns in individuals with severe disability.
results_summary: All nine participants showed increased symbolic communication turns after the introduction of AAC technologies with VSDs and JIT programming, suggesting the intervention was effective in enhancing communication for this population. The study highlights the potential of VSDs and JIT as valuable tools for interventionists.
population_specificity: School-age children, adolescents, and young adults (ages 8-20) with severe developmental disability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how Visual Scene Displays (VSDs) relate to user visual and cognitive processing in aided AAC interventions.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that understanding visual-cognitive processing is critical for designing effective VSDs, but direct research with children with complex communication needs is needed to verify their speculations.
population_specificity: Persons with intellectual disabilities and complex communication needs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a communication app with just-in-time programmed Visual Scene Displays (VSDs) on the communication turns of preadolescent and adolescent beginning communicators.
results_summary: All five participants showed significant increases in communication frequency after the intervention. The study concluded that just-in-time programming and VSDs positively impact communication for beginning communicators in this age group.
population_specificity: Preadolescents and adolescents (9-18 years old) who were beginning communicators.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between Vitamin A and autism spectrum disorder (ASD), focusing on how VA deficiency and supplementation affect autistic symptomatology.
results_summary: The study found that Vitamin A deficiency can worsen autistic symptoms, while supplementation may improve symptoms in certain ASD subgroups. However, ASD's heterogeneity means VA's benefits vary among individuals.
population_specificity: Individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and selected autistic syndromes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance β-carotene (pro-vitamin A) accumulation and bioaccessibility in green leafy vegetables using metabolic engineering and light-intensity treatments.
results_summary: Combining cytosolic β-carotene production (strategy C) and plastid conversion (strategy P) increased β-carotene levels 5-fold in Nicotiana benthamiana leaves, while adding high-light treatment boosted accessible β-carotene 30-fold. Similar improvements were observed in edible lettuce leaves.
population_specificity: Nicotiana benthamiana and Lactuca sativa (lettuce) leaves.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the associations between maternal vitamin A status during pregnancy and offspring bone mineral content (BMC) at nine years of age.
results_summary: The study found a high prevalence of vitamin A insufficiency during pregnancy and a negative association between mid-pregnancy vitamin A status and spine BMC in boys, but not in girls. No other associations between maternal vitamin A and child BMC were observed.
population_specificity: Pregnant women from two Norwegian cities (Trondheim and Stavanger) and their children at nine years of age.
study_duration: Measurements taken during the 2nd and 3rd trimesters of pregnancy; child BMC assessed at nine years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of Vitamin A on intestinal glucose metabolic phenotypes, particularly its role in glucose-stimulated insulin secretion and GLP-1 expression.
results_summary: Vitamin A deficiency (VAD) led to reduced glucose-stimulated insulin secretion and loss of intestinal GLP-1 expression, which were restored upon reintroducing Vitamin A. Activation of retinoic acid receptor β (RARβ) in STC-1 cells restored incretin hormone synthesis and secretory function.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 mice
study_duration: 12 weeks (VAD/VAN diet) + 10 days (retinol intervention) + 10 weeks (VAN diet)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether adding oral vitamin A to olfactory training improved COVID-19-related olfactory dysfunction compared to olfactory training alone.
results_summary: The study found that olfactory training improved smell alteration in COVID-19 patients, but adding daily oral vitamin A did not lead to better results compared to olfactory training alone.
population_specificity: Patients with COVID-19-related olfactory dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between vitamin A deficiency at diagnosis of pediatric acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and subsequent infectious complications during induction therapy.
results_summary: Vitamin A deficiency was common (43%) and associated with a lower risk of sepsis (aHR, 0.19; P = .027), but no other significant associations with infection-related complications were found.
population_specificity: Children with newly diagnosed ALL at St. Jude Children's Research Hospital (2007-2017).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Vitamin A as an adjuvant therapy for pediatric Mycoplasma Pneumoniae Pneumonia (MPP) and its impact on inflammation levels (IL-6, IL-10).
results_summary: Vitamin A adjuvant therapy significantly improved clinical efficacy, reduced hospitalization time, and alleviated symptoms like cough and fever. It also lowered inflammation markers (IL-6 and IL-10), indicating anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with Mycoplasma Pneumoniae Pneumonia (MPP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether feeding cull cows a low vitamin A (LVA) diet for 56 days would improve carcass yield, quality traits, and the conversion of yellow to white subcutaneous fat compared to a high vitamin A (HVA) diet.
results_summary: The study found that cows fed the LVA diet exhibited decreased adipose yellowness and β-carotene concentrations, increased live weights, and differences in subcutaneous fat color compared to the HVA diet. Subjective fat color scores and β-carotene concentrations were significantly different between treatments by day 56.
population_specificity: 98 Angus crossbreed cull cows
effective_dosage: Not specified (low vs. high vitamin A diets, exact amounts not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to simulate the impact of dietary Vitamin A intake and daily supplements on Vitamin A total body stores and balance in lactating women with low/moderate Vitamin A stores.
results_summary: The study found that increasing Vitamin A intake or adding a daily supplement (2.8 μmol/d) effectively countered negative Vitamin A balance caused by lactation, maintaining or increasing Vitamin A stores and breastmilk concentration. Without supplementation, Vitamin A balance was negative, but supplementation resulted in positive balance.
population_specificity: Theoretical lactating women with low/moderate Vitamin A total body stores.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the treatment mode and molecular mechanism of tetramethylpyrazine (TMP) combined with retinoic acid (RA) in alleviating skin photoaging.
results_summary: The study found that TMP combined with RA alleviates skin oxidative stress and photoaging by reducing ROS enrichment and activating the Nrf2/ARE signaling pathway, with enhanced effects compared to TMP alone.
population_specificity: HaCaT cells and mice with skin photoaging.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to document the ocular manifestations and treatment outcomes of vitamin A deficiency retinopathy in an adult patient with celiac disease and liver fibrosis.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin A deficiency retinopathy presented with characteristic retinal and electrophysiologic changes, which improved significantly after high-dose vitamin A therapy, including restored ERG responses and outer retinal architecture, along with improved visual acuity.
population_specificity: A 77-year-old male with celiac disease and liver fibrosis.
effective_dosage: Pulse vitamin A therapy (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a controlled-release Vitamin A palmitate (VAP) eye drop system using a crosslinked cyclodextrin organic framework (COF) to improve ocular surface residence time and treat dry eye disease (DED).
results_summary: The VAP@COF suspension exhibited controlled release within 12 hours, prolonged ocular surface residence time, accelerated recovery in a rabbit DED model, and showed no cytotoxicity or irritation.
population_specificity: New Zealand rabbits and human corneal epithelial cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the preventive effects of vitamin A supplements on clinically important outcomes, including mortality, adverse events, and quality of life, compared to placebo or no intervention in people of any age.
results_summary: Vitamin A did not reduce mortality in individually randomised trials (moderate certainty evidence) but showed a reduction in cluster randomised trials (very low certainty evidence). No serious adverse events or quality of life outcomes were reported, though vitamin A slightly increased bulging fontanelle in neonates and infants.
population_specificity: Children (78 individually randomised trials, 14 cluster randomised trials) and adults (27 individually randomised trials, 1 cluster randomised trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential link between vitamin A deficiency and the development of bilateral Bartholin's gland abscesses in a prepubertal child.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin A deficiency likely contributed to decreased immunocompetence and mucosal barrier function, leading to bilateral Bartholin's gland abscesses in a 4-year-old girl. Nutritional supplementation corrected the deficiency, and no abscess recurrence was observed after three months.
population_specificity: A 4-year-old girl with autism spectrum disorder and vitamin A deficiency.
study_duration: During hospitalization (8 days) and follow-up (3 months)

study_goal: To assess the effectiveness and safety of vitamin A supplements for preventing acute upper respiratory tract infections (URTIs) in children up to seven years of age.
results_summary: The study found uncertain evidence for vitamin A supplementation in preventing acute URTIs, with no clear benefit observed. Adverse events were minimal, but the certainty of evidence was very low to low.
population_specificity: Children up to seven years old, including healthy children, those born to HIV-infected women, low-birthweight neonates, and children in areas with high malnutrition and xerophthalmia prevalence.
study_duration: Varied across studies (not specified in the abstract).
interactions: Vitamin E was a co-treatment in two studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the reliability and accuracy of a portable device versus HPLC for quantifying vitamin A in fortified oils.
results_summary: The study found high agreement between the portable device and HPLC, with good repeatability (<10% CV) and strong correlation (r=0.88) for vitamin A quantification in commercially fortified oils. Vitamin A recoveries were 97-132% for HPLC and 74-127% for the portable device.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on fortified oils, not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study measured vitamin A content in oils, not administered dosages).
study_duration: Not specified (laboratory analysis, not an intervention study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Vitamin A could rescue the long-lasting functional impairment of celiac lymph nodes caused by transient gastrointestinal infections in neonates.
results_summary: The study found that early-life Vitamin A treatment restored the tolerogenic properties of celiac lymph node stromal cells impaired by neonatal infections, highlighting its therapeutic potential to prevent long-term immune dysfunction.
population_specificity: Neonates (infants) with transient gastrointestinal infections.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of vitamin A status in lung epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and its relationship with TGF-β activation and furin expression.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin A deficiency (VAD) induces EMT and furin expression, while retinoic acid (RA) treatment further increases furin expression and alters EMT markers, suggesting both deficiency and excess of vitamin A can disrupt lung homeostasis.
population_specificity: Rats (in vivo) and human bronchoalveolar epithelial cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dietary vitamin A supplementation on tibial growth, calcium and phosphorus metabolism, vitamin A and D deposition, and related gene expression in goslings.
results_summary: No vitamin A supplementation reduced vitamin A levels in serum and liver, while 15,000 IU/kg increased it. Both no supplementation and high-dose vitamin A negatively affected tibia length, strength, and mineral content, as well as reduced vitamin D levels and bone-related gene expression.
population_specificity: 1-day-old male goslings

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA), the active metabolite of vitamin A, on periosteal osteoclast progenitors in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: ATRA robustly potentiated the formation of RANKL-induced bone-resorbing osteoclasts by stimulating macrophage/osteoclast progenitor numbers in periosteal cell cultures but did not enhance macrophages in bone marrow cell cultures. ATRA also upregulated macrophage-related gene expression in the periosteum of adult mice.
population_specificity: Mouse calvarial bone cells (in vitro) and adult mice (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether altered dietary vitamin A intake (deficient or copious) affects the pathogenesis of alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) in mice.
results_summary: The study found that varying vitamin A intake (deficient or copious) did not significantly alter alcohol-induced changes in hepatic triglyceride levels, lipid metabolism, inflammation, or fibrosis compared to control. Hepatic vitamin A storage changes had a minor effect on ALD pathogenesis.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to the NIAAA chronic-binge model of ALD.
effective_dosage: Deficient (0 IU/g diet), control (4 IU/g diet), copious (25 IU/g diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how dietary vitamin A affects gut microbiota, intestinal permeability, inflammatory factors, and Aβ pathology in an Alzheimer's disease mouse model.
results_summary: Vitamin A supplementation modulated gut microbiota, reduced inflammatory markers, and lowered Aβ levels compared to deficient groups, suggesting potential benefits for AD prevention and treatment. However, cognitive performance was best in the normal vitamin A group, not the supplemented group.
population_specificity: APP/PS1-AD mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early postnatal high-dose enteral vitamin A supplementation reduces the rate of moderate or severe bronchopulmonary dysplasia or death in extremely low birthweight infants.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the rate of moderate or severe bronchopulmonary dysplasia or death between the high-dose vitamin A and control groups. Adverse events and serum retinol concentrations were similar in both groups.
population_specificity: Extremely low birthweight infants (birthweight 400-1000 g, gestational age ≤32 weeks) requiring respiratory support within 72 hours of birth.
effective_dosage: 5000 IU/kg per day (high-dose) versus 1000 IU/kg per day (basic supplementation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the therapeutic benefits of vitamin A supplementation in reducing hospitalization length and pneumonic effusion duration in pediatric CAP patients under five years old.
results_summary: Vitamin A supplementation significantly reduced hospitalization length by 2.39 days and shortened pneumonic effusion duration compared to the control group, demonstrating clinically meaningful benefits.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients under five years old with severe pneumonia in the intensive care unit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the risk potential of vitamin A supplements by evaluating labeling compliance, dosage levels, and safety warnings in German and US markets.
results_summary: The study found serious deficiencies in labeling compliance and excessively high dosages in both German and US supplements, with US products performing slightly better. The hepatotoxicity and teratogenicity of vitamin A were highlighted, raising concerns about over-the-counter availability.
population_specificity: Vitamin A supplements available in Germany (75 products) and the USA (26 products).
effective_dosage: Not specified (varies by product, often exceeding expert recommendations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the importance of early detection and intervention for vitamin A deficiency (VAD) in pediatric patients, particularly those with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), and to demonstrate the effectiveness of vitamin A supplementation in resolving VAD symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin A supplementation resolved severe VAD symptoms, including photophobia and reluctance to leave a darkened room, in a 10-year-old girl with ASD within three weeks. It emphasized the need for routine dietary discussions and micronutrient testing in ASD patients to prevent deficiencies.
population_specificity: A 10-year-old girl with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and a self-restricted diet of fast-food french fries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the importance of recognizing and managing severe vitamin A deficiency in pediatric patients with infectious hepatitis.
results_summary: The study found that prompt nutritional supplementation with vitamin A, alongside antiviral therapy and supportive care, resolved symptoms and normalized liver enzymes in a child with hepatitis-associated severe vitamin A deficiency. The case underscores the need for comprehensive care in overlapping infectious and nutritional conditions.
population_specificity: A three-year-old male child with acute hepatitis and severe vitamin A deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-dose vitamin A supplementation could improve bone remodeling and clinical signs in young lion cubs with calvarial hyperostosis.
results_summary: Vitamin A supplementation led to reduced bone thickening, improved neurologic status, and amelioration of cervical hyperintensities, though mild cerebellar herniation persisted. The study suggests bone remodeling and clinical improvement are achievable with vitamin A treatment in affected cubs.
population_specificity: 11-week-old captive African lion cubs (Panthera leo leo) with calvarial hyperostosis and mild vestibular signs.
effective_dosage: Not specified (subcutaneous vitamin A supplementation and whole carcass feeding).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the feasibility and coverage of vitamin A supplementation and deworming (VASD) delivered by community health volunteers versus bi-annual campaign events in Kenya.
results_summary: The study found that community health volunteers achieved higher coverage (90.6% for VAS, 73.9% for deworming) compared to the campaign (70.4% for VAS, 54.7% for deworming), demonstrating superior effectiveness of the CHV approach.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-59 months in sub-counties of Siaya County, Kenya.

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of combining 0.05% cyclosporine A eye drops with vitamin A palmitate eye gel in treating dry eye associated with meibomian gland dysfunction (MGD).
results_summary: The combination of cyclosporine A and vitamin A palmitate significantly improved symptoms and signs of MGD-related dry eye, particularly tear film lipid layer thickness and meibomian gland secretion in severe cases, outperforming other treatment groups.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with MGD-associated dry eye (110 participants).
effective_dosage: Vitamin A palmitate eye gel three times a day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if vitamin A deficiency (VAD) was the cause of persistent corneal epithelial damage and reduced vision in a patient post-cataract surgery, and to assess the effectiveness of vitamin A supplementation in reversing these symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin A supplementation normalized visual acuity, electroretinograms (ERGs), and retinal structure in a VAD patient, with significant improvements observed after three months of treatment.
population_specificity: A 74-year-old man with persistent corneal epithelial damage and reduced vision post-cataract surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the roles and mechanisms of Vitamin A derivatives (retinoic acid, retinal, β-carotene) in cell differentiation, disease prevention, and treatment, as well as evaluate a novel Vitamin A derivative (p-DDAP) for anticancer effects.
results_summary: The study found that retinoic acid (RA) induces cell differentiation and is used therapeutically for acute promyelocytic leukemia. It also identified retinoylation as a novel non-genomic RA mechanism and highlighted the anticancer potential of p-DDAP, a new Vitamin A derivative.
population_specificity: Not specified (general mechanisms and in vitro HL60 cells mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the regulatory effects of Vitamin A (VA) and retinoic acid (RA) on mitochondrial biogenesis, muscle fiber composition, and the underlying mechanisms in sheep.
results_summary: VA and RA increased type I myofibers, enhanced mitochondrial biogenesis and function, and upregulated PGC-1α expression via the p38 MAPK pathway in sheep muscle. Inhibition of PGC-1α or p38 MAPK reversed these effects, confirming their role in VA/RA-mediated changes.
population_specificity: Newborn lambs (in vivo) and primary myoblasts from sheep (in vitro).
effective_dosage: 7,500 IU VA palmitate injected once into the biceps femoris muscle on day 2 after birth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of red palm olein-enriched biscuits in improving vitamin A, hematological, iron, and inflammatory status among vitamin A-deficient schoolchildren.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in retinol and retinol-binding protein levels in both groups, with greater enhancements in provitamin A carotenes, iron, and erythropoiesis in the experimental group. The experimental group also showed a significant reduction in microcytic anemia and high inflammation.
population_specificity: 651 rural primary schoolchildren (8-12 years) with vitamin A deficiency in Malaysia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between rare genetic variations in vitamin A-related genes and autism spectrum disorder (ASD) aetiology, and to compare the roles of vitamin A and oxytocin in ASD.
results_summary: The study found that functional de novo mutations and pathogenic copy number variations in vitamin A-related genes contribute to ASD pathogenesis. Additionally, 324 potential vitamin A-related biomarkers were identified, with 243 shared with oxytocin-related biomarkers, and both sets of biomarkers could predict ASD aetiology with high precision.
population_specificity: Approximately 50,000 ASD probands and 20,000 normal controls (discovery and validation cohorts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin A supplementation mediates the association between serum vitamin K levels and musculoskeletal disorders (MSD) in preschool children.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin A and D supplementation partly mediated (36.8%) the association between low serum vitamin K1 levels and MSD prevalence, suggesting a beneficial role in preventing MSD in children with vitamin K deficiency.
population_specificity: Preschool children aged 0-6 years in Sichuan province, China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the sources, etiology, epidemiology, pathophysiology, and treatment of vitamin A deficiency in humans.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the importance of vitamin A for physiological processes, its sources in animal-based products and plant carotenoids, and the body's ability to convert it into active forms. It also addresses retinol deficiency but does not provide specific efficacy outcomes.
population_specificity: Humans (general population, not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neonatal intramuscular Vitamin A injection could improve antioxidative activity and meat quality in the longissimus dorsi muscle of lambs.
results_summary: Vitamin A increased redness, crude protein, and crude fat in the muscle without affecting moisture, ash, or amino acid composition. It also enhanced antioxidative capacity by increasing catalase activity, reducing malondialdehyde levels, and upregulating CAT and NRF2 mRNA and protein expression.
population_specificity: Lambs (neonatal to 32 weeks old)
effective_dosage: 7,500 IU VA palmitate, single intramuscular injection
study_duration: Single dose at 2 days old, effects measured up to 32 weeks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between blood vitamin A levels and the risk of diabetic retinopathy in a population-based study.
results_summary: Higher serum vitamin A levels were associated with a lower risk of diabetic retinopathy, particularly in males and adults under 60. The odds ratios for the highest quartile of vitamin A were significantly protective (OR 0.32 overall, 0.11 in males, and 0.10 in adults under 60).
population_specificity: 11,727 Korean participants aged 40 or older from the Korean National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey.
effective_dosage: Not specified (classified into quartiles based on blood levels).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of vitamin A supplementation and surgical intervention in treating persistent Bitot's spots due to vitamin A deficiency, particularly in a young adult case.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin A supplementation alone was insufficient for resolving persistent Bitot's spots in the case, but surgical excision followed by amniotic membrane transplantation led to symptom relief and epithelialization without recurrence. Histopathologic analysis revealed impaired goblet cell differentiation due to vitamin A deficiency.
population_specificity: 34-year-old male with persistent Bitot's spots despite vitamin A supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of Vitamin A in longevity and age-related diseases, specifically its impact on lifespan, oxidative stress resistance, and fat accumulation.
results_summary: Vitamin A extended lifespan, reduced lipofuscin and fat accumulation, and increased resistance to heat and oxidative stress in C. elegans, human cells, and mice, mediated by the SKN-1/NRF2 pathway.
population_specificity: Caenorhabditis elegans, human cells, and liver tissues of mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify risk factors for vitamin A deficiency in pregnant women and assess its impact on maternal, fetal, and neonatal health, as well as the effects of high-dose supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that inadequate vitamin A intake during pregnancy and lactation can lead to anemia, weakened immunity, and night blindness, while excessive intake may cause birth defects and hypercalcemia. It emphasized the need for balanced vitamin A levels to improve fetal and neonatal outcomes.
population_specificity: Pregnant and lactating women, fetuses, and neonates.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intranasally delivered vitamin A could improve olfactory function in patients with post-viral smell loss compared to no intervention.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study is described as a planned two-arm randomized trial to establish proof of concept for vitamin A's regenerative potential in olfactory neurons.
population_specificity: Patients with post-viral olfactory loss recruited from the Smell & Taste Clinic and via the charity Fifth Sense.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate cases of vitamin A deficiency retinopathy caused by malabsorption secondary to medical interventions.
results_summary: The study identified five cases of vitamin A deficiency retinopathy linked to malabsorption from medical interventions, with symptoms including night blindness and abnormal retinal findings. Vitamin A deficiency was confirmed via laboratory tests, highlighting the need for monitoring levels in at-risk patients.
population_specificity: Patients with malabsorption due to bariatric surgery, small bowel resection, octreotide treatment, or cystic fibrosis.

study_goal: To evaluate whether nightly topical ophthalmic vitamin A ointment, combined with PROSE device use, mitigates disease progression in chronic ocular surface disease associated with Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS).
results_summary: The study found that nightly topical vitamin A ointment, alongside PROSE use, appeared to halt disease progression in a patient with chronic SJS-related ocular surface disease. Non-compliance with vitamin A ointment led to disease progression, which stabilized upon resumption of treatment.
population_specificity: A 51-year-old female with chronic ocular surface disease secondary to SJS.
effective_dosage: Nightly application of topical ophthalmic vitamin A ointment (specific dosage not provided).
study_duration: 4 years of follow-up after restarting treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of varying vitamin A supplementation levels on performance, organ weight, and bone and skin characteristics in broilers at 21 and 42 days of age.
results_summary: Vitamin A supplementation influenced feed intake and body weight gain, with optimal effects observed at specific levels (28,209 IU/kg at 21 days and 29,375 IU/kg at 42 days). It also improved organ weights and bone strength, but supplementation beyond 21 days did not further enhance performance.
population_specificity: Broiler chickens (Cobb 500)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate plasma Vitamin A levels and amino acid profiles in celiac disease patients, comparing active and treated cases to healthy controls.
results_summary: Active adult CD patients showed decreased Vitamin A levels compared to controls, while treated patients exhibited altered amino acid profiles and cytokine expression, suggesting potential impacts on intestinal damage and inflammation.
population_specificity: 60 children and adults with celiac disease (CD) and 40 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy on serum levels of Vitamin A and other nutrients in obese patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in serum Vitamin A levels before and after surgery, suggesting the procedure does not lead to Vitamin A deficiency.
population_specificity: Obese patients (mean BMI 43.6 ± 4.4 kg/m²) undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy in Tehran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how Vitamin A (9-cis retinoic acid) and Vitamin D metabolites impact B cell differentiation, immunoglobulin class switching, and immune responses in allergy and autoimmunity.
results_summary: The study found that Vitamin A (9cRA) and calcitriol together induce naïve B cell differentiation into IgA+ plasmablasts, potentially balancing immune responses in conditions like allergy and autoimmunity, though molecular mechanisms require further investigation.
population_specificity: Human B cells (in vitro or ex vivo context, not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between gut microbiota, vitamin A metabolism, and bladder cancer prevention.
results_summary: The study found that bladder cancer patients had reduced serum vitamin A levels and gut microbiota imbalances, suggesting a complex regulatory mechanism between the two. It highlights the potential of gut microbiota in guiding vitamin A use for bladder cancer prevention.
population_specificity: Bladder cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify risk factors and fundus imaging features of vitamin A deficiency retinopathy (VADR) and propose diagnostic and management guidance.
results_summary: Vitamin A deficiency retinopathy was linked to gastrointestinal surgery, liver disease, and poor diet. Supplementation improved many symptoms, but retinal damage persisted in cases with longstanding deficiency.
population_specificity: Nine patients (median age 68) diagnosed with VADR at a tertiary referral center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) modulate colonic epithelial barrier integrity in Vitamin A deficiency (VAD) and whether Vitamin A supplementation can reverse gut barrier damage.
results_summary: The study found that Vitamin A deficiency impaired colonic desmosome junctions and reduced SCFA levels due to decreased SCFA-producing bacteria. Vitamin A supplementation in the early postnatal period reversed these effects, and butyrate treatment in Caco-2 cells restored CEACAM1 expression by inhibiting HDAC3 enrichment.
population_specificity: Pregnant rats and Caco-2 cells (human cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin A could mitigate the negative effects of heat stress on rabbit dermal papilla cells and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Vitamin A (0.4 mg/L) enhanced cell proliferation, reduced apoptosis, and modulated key signaling pathways (miR-195/IGF1 and Wnt10b/β-catenin) under heat stress, though these effects were attenuated when the pathways were blocked.
population_specificity: Rabbit dermal papilla cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of food-based approaches on improving vitamin A status in women and children under 5 years, focusing on provitamin A carotenoids and preformed vitamin A.
results_summary: The review found that 54% of studies reported a statistically significant effect of food-based interventions or dietary associations on vitamin A status, though effectiveness varied due to differences in evaluation periods, food approaches, and statistical power. Some food-based interventions were deemed safe and effective for delivering vitamin A.
population_specificity: Women and children under 5 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight a rare case of vitamin A deficiency (VAD) secondary to malabsorption in a Crohn's disease patient and emphasize the importance of systemic evaluation for ophthalmic symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin A deficiency caused severe dry eyes, blurred vision, and nyctalopia in the patient, which improved with intramuscular vitamin A treatment. It underscores the need for regular vitamin A checks in at-risk populations.
population_specificity: A 56-year-old male with Crohn's disease and pancreatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate plasma levels of vitamin A (as retinol-binding protein, RBP) in Malawian infants and assess its association with nutritional status and growth.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin A deficiency was present in 8% of infants, with no differences between HIV-exposed and unexposed infants. Vitamin A deficiency was not associated with stunting, being underweight, or wasting.
population_specificity: Breastfed Malawian infants (HIV-exposed and unexposed) aged 6-12 months.
study_duration: Observational follow-up from 6 to 12 months of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a short-course oral Vitamin A combined with olfactory training could effectively treat persistent olfactory dysfunction in long COVID patients.
results_summary: The combination of Vitamin A and olfactory training significantly improved olfactory function compared to control and standard care groups, with measurable increases in butanol threshold and smell identification test scores, as well as enhanced functional connectivity in the olfactory cortical network.
population_specificity: Long COVID patients with persistent olfactory dysfunction (median duration 157 days).
study_duration: 4 weeks (14 days of Vitamin A administration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin A-derivative decorated polymeric micelles could effectively target hepatic stellate cells (HSCs) and inhibit their glycolysis and expansion to suppress liver fibrogenesis.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin A-decorated micelles effectively delivered camptothecin (CPT) to HSCs, inhibiting HIF-1α and glycolytic enzymes, suppressing HSC proliferation, and ameliorating liver fibrosis in mice. The treatment also reduced inflammatory markers and collagen accumulation while restoring liver function.
population_specificity: Mice with liver fibrosis induced by CCl4 injection or bile duct ligation (BDL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of vitamin A replacement therapy in a pediatric patient with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and severe vitamin A deficiency leading to xerophthalmia and keratomalacia.
results_summary: Vitamin A replacement therapy (intramuscular and oral) improved ocular symptoms, allowing the patient to open both eyes and show interest in tablet devices within 14 days, though corneal perforation occurred but healed without additional interventions.
population_specificity: A 6-year-old boy with ASD and severe vitamin A deficiency.
effective_dosage: Intramuscular vitamin A (50,000 IU/day) and oral multivitamin (containing 2,500 IU of vitamin A) plus zinc supplement (50 mg/day).
study_duration: 14 days (primary improvement noted), with ongoing management.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of early intramuscular vitamin A injection on muscle growth and myogenic potential in lambs.
results_summary: Vitamin A treatment accelerated lamb growth rate, increased loin eye area, myofiber diameter, and final body weight. It also upregulated myogenic gene expression and enhanced in vitro myogenic differentiation of skeletal muscle-derived cells.
population_specificity: Newborn lambs
study_duration: From birth to 3 weeks of age (4 injections total)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether dietary vitamin A affects incretin-secreting cell function and gene expression in mice fed a high-fat diet.
results_summary: Rbp2-/- mice showed greater weight gain on a normal vitamin A diet compared to a low vitamin A diet, with elevated GIP levels on the normal diet and reduced GIP and GLP-1 responses on the low vitamin A diet. Changes in gene expression supported these findings, with no systemic vitamin A deficiency observed.
population_specificity: Male Rbp2-/- mice and sex- and age-matched controls.
effective_dosage: Normal vitamin A (4000 IU/kg of diet) and low vitamin A (25% of normal, 1000 IU/kg of diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of vitamin A (isolated and combined with zinc) on intestinal functionality, morphology, and the gut microbiome in Gallus gallus.
results_summary: Vitamin A administration (especially at low doses) increased duodenal surface area and modulated gut bacteria, reducing Bifidobacterium and Clostridium genera. Combined with zinc, it improved intestinal epithelium functionality.
population_specificity: Fertile broiler eggs (Gallus gallus).
effective_dosage: Normal retinoid (1500 IU/kg retinyl palmitate), low retinoid (100 IU/kg).
study_duration: Administered via intra-amniotic injection; tissue samples collected upon hatch.
interactions: Interaction with zinc noted, particularly in combined treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether co-supplementation of Vitamin A and probiotics enhances the humoral immune response to rabies vaccine in rabbits.
results_summary: Vitamin A and probiotic co-supplementation significantly increased rabies antibody titers compared to controls, with the highest sero-conversion observed on day 35. The addition of organic carrots further boosted antibody production.
population_specificity: New Zealand white rabbits

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin A-modified nanoparticles could effectively target hepatic stellate cells to treat liver fibrosis.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin A-modified nanoparticles successfully targeted hepatic stellate cells, improved liver fibrosis, and reduced liver injury in vivo. The pH-sensitive delivery system controlled drug release and increased local drug concentration at the fibrosis site.
population_specificity: In vivo model (specific species not mentioned in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether and how Vitamin A affects intestinal metabolic phenotypes, focusing on its role in intestinal microbiota, inflammatory response, and permeability.
results_summary: Vitamin A deficiency (VAD) led to decreased tissue VA levels, altered intestinal microbiota, increased inflammatory cytokines, and higher intestinal permeability. Reintroducing VA restored these parameters to levels similar to those in VA-sufficient mice, suggesting VA's critical role in maintaining intestinal homeostasis.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 mice after weaning, during pregnancy and lactation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (VA control diet vs. VA-deficient diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of vitamin A in conjunction with vitamin D3 in preserving visual function in dopamine-deficient mice with movement disorders.
results_summary: Vitamin A, when combined with vitamin D3, prevented retinal and visual cortex deterioration by reducing oxidative stress and cytotoxicity, though vitamin A alone did not fully mitigate the damage observed in dopamine-deficient mice.
population_specificity: Male mice with induced dopamine deficits (movement disorder model).
effective_dosage: 1000 IU/day of vitamin A (concurrently with 800 IU/day of vitamin D3 in one group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of Vitamin A deficiency (VAD) among pregnant women in Ethiopia and identify factors contributing to VAD to propose intervention strategies.
results_summary: The study found that 29% of pregnant women in Ethiopia had VAD, with socio-economic and sociodemographic factors influencing deficiency rates. The authors recommended interventions to increase vitamin A-rich food intake to reduce VAD.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in Ethiopia (37,618 participants from 15 studies).
